channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: The labor market is cooling, so now would be the time for companies to invest in existing employees. But employers aren’t doing that, research shows
item.description: Despite a modest increase in hiring demand in the first half of this year, internal hiring and promotion rates have actually fallen.

item.title: ‘Bad data is AI’s kryptonite’: Experts suggest businesses fix their data first before investing too much in AI
item.description: Nearly two-thirds of practitioners indicated a lack of “high-quality data” for use with AI at their organizations.

item.title: ChatGPT went from homework helper to confidant to ‘suicide coach,’ parents testify in Congress after teen’s death
item.description: Parents also testified about their teens being "groomed" by highly-sexualized chatbots.

item.title: Trump’s Birthday Call to Modi Raises Hopes in India for a Trade Deal
item.description: The call coincided with a visit by U.S. trade officials to the country, which just weeks ago was hit with a 50 percent tariff on all imports to the Un...

item.title: Investors Are Bullish as a Pivotal Fed Decision Looms
item.description: The S&P 500 is in record territory, and investors are pricing in a quarter-point cut to interest rates on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump crackdown on ‘radical left’ after Charlie Kirk’s death targets Soros, Indivisible despite evidence of lone shooter
item.description: President Trump has made retribution against political enemies a cornerstone of his campaign.

item.title: Catholic Boy Scouts chair sees ‘a hunger out there now for finding a values-based organization’ as scandal recovery continues
item.description: The biggest blow came in 2020, when Mormons snubbed the Scouts and took 400,000 members.

item.title: Climate Change’s Toll in Europe This Summer: Thousands of Extra Deaths
item.description: Three times as many people in cities and towns died from severe heat as would have done in a world without human-caused warming, scientists said.

item.title: How Nepal’s Government Went Up in Smoke
item.description: Arson attacks during protests in Nepal destroyed buildings, court files and even records of international agreements and state investments.

item.title: How Did Hands Evolve? Look to Your Anus, a New Study Suggests.
item.description: The evolutionary blueprint for hands was borrowed in part from a much older genetic plan for our nether regions, a new study suggests.

item.title: Live Updates: U.K. Gives Trump a Royal Welcome in 2nd State Visit
item.description: With a carriage ride at Windsor Castle and dinner with King Charles III, Britain tries to appeal to a president who has seemed intent on upending the ...

item.title: How Nepal’s Government Went Up in Smoke
item.description: Arson attacks during protests in Nepal destroyed buildings, court files and even records of international agreements and state investments.

item.title: Climate Change’s Toll in Europe This Summer: Thousands of Extra Deaths
item.description: Three times as many people in cities and towns died from severe heat as would have done in a world without human-caused warming, scientists said.

item.title: What Democrats Can Learn From Charlie Kirk
item.description: He built one of the most effective youth mobilization machines in recent memory.
